In order to expand the immunity of the population and protect the most vulnerable people against the virus, the vaccination must take place over three phases, depending on the number of available doses.    GROUP 1a    In the first instance, the most vulnerable and exposed people will receive the vaccine.    Residents and employees in residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit the elderly particularly hard, principally those in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, then the corresponding staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  Medical personnel from first-line care and hospitals: they are in close contact with COVID-19 patients every day. To protect them, they will be prioritised for vaccination.  The other staff in hospitals and healthcare centres will be vaccinated, including organisations which work in prevention activities, such as vaccination centres and cancer screening centres, Child and Family and ONE.  GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical issues, but at high risk    In this phase, priority was given to people outside hospitals, who are at the highest risk. It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. We have started with the oldest people and then go down through the age groups.  Patients aged 18 to 64 with: â¢ chronic kidney disease present for at least 3 months â¢ chronic liver disease present for at least 6 months â¢ haematological cancers (eg leukemia) â¢ down syndrome â¢ transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) â¢ impaired immune system i.e. suffer from an immunodeficiency or take immunosuppressants â¢ active HIV/AIDS â¢ Some rare diseases belonging to the official lists of rare diseases  Patients aged 45 to 64 with: â¢ Chronic severe respiratory disease â¢ chronic cardiovascular disease â¢ obesity (obesity) with BMI = 30 â¢ diabetes type I and II â¢ chronic nervous system disorders â¢ dementia â¢ cancer (tumours) no more than 5 years ago â¢ elevated blood pressure at least 14O mmHG systolic or at least 90 mmHg diastolic    Pregnant women: to be vaccinated as a priority, they must contact their regular GP. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN).    GROUP 2 - broader population from 12 years old    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212151840/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/

An additional dose of the vaccine is now recommended for the whole population. Following the approval recieved from the European Medicines Agency,  the Consultative Committee has asked that the Supreme Health Council and the Advisory Committee on Bioethics give their opinion on a date to start vaccinating 5- to 11-year-olds on a voluntary basis.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127094244/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/occ-2611/

It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. We have started with the oldest people and then go down through the age groups.  Patients aged 18 to 64 with: â¢ chronic kidney disease present for at least 3 months â¢ chronic liver disease present for at least 6 months â¢ haematological cancers (eg leukemia) â¢ down syndrome â¢ transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) â¢ impaired immune system i.e. suffer from an immunodeficiency or take immunosuppressants â¢ active HIV/AIDS â¢ Some rare diseases belonging to the official lists of rare diseases  Patients aged 45 to 64 with: â¢ Chronic severe respiratory disease â¢ chronic cardiovascular disease â¢ obesity (obesity) with BMI = 30 â¢ diabetes type I and II â¢ chronic nervous system disorders â¢ dementia â¢ cancer (tumours) no more than 5 years ago â¢ elevated blood pressure at least 14O mmHG systolic or at least 90 mmHg diastolic    Pregnant women: to be vaccinated as a priority, they must contact their regular GP. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN).    GROUP 2 - broader population from 12 years old    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212151840/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/

Group classes for adults in language centers, educational centers, and other training centers and schools are suspended. Conducting face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed provided at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers. The present learning process in the higher schools is terminated. Learning for students from 1-12th grade is suspended. Students from 5-12tth grade must wear a mask in class.   https://archive.vn/QUcwF

Conducting face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed provided at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, symposiums, trainings, competitions, exams and other group events of this nature is suspended. Teambuilding and other organized group events of this nature in work teams are suspended. Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (distance work / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of at most 50% of the staff. Working hours are between 7.30 am and 10.00 am. 50% of staff must be remote unless impossible. Essential workers but have valid vaccination, illness, or testing documents.   https://archive.vn/QUcwF

Employers and appointment bodies in all administrations within the meaning of Art. 1 of the Administration Act organize the work process of the employees, as: (a) establish working hours with variable limits and the start of the working day between 7.30 am and 10.00 am, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work; (b) assign remote work to at least 50% of staff, unless this is not possible depending on the nature of the work.  Employers in hospitals, complex oncology centers, dialysis centers, hospices and nursing homes organize the work process by admitting to work only employees with valid documents for vaccination, illness or testing within the meaning of this order.   Visits to fitness centers, sports halls and clubs, swimming pools and complexes, balneotherapy (medical SPA) centers, SPA centers, wellness centers and thalassotherapy centers are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation. Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications operators' offices, whether they are stand-alone or located in a shopping center type Mall. Exercise a high degree of caution when entering Bulgaria. Avoid non-essential travel in or out of the country due to the omicron variant. The EU follows the light system with different testing, quarantine, and vaccination policies.   https://archive.vn/zAoJL

Green & Orange zone - persons are admitted to the territory of the country upon presentation of a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination, disease or testing or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate. Persons who do not present a document shall be placed under quarantine for 10 days in the home or other place of accommodation in which the person has indicated that he will reside, with a prescription issued by the director of the relevant regional health inspectorate or authorized by his deputy director. The quarantined person may carry out a polymerase chain reaction test to detect COVID-19 or a rapid antigen test of those listed in Annex ? 2 not earlier than 72 hours of arrival in the country. In case of a negative result of the conducted research, the quarantine of the person shall be considered terminated from the day following the registration of the result in the National Information System for Combating COVID-19.  Red zone - on the territory of the country are allowed only persons who meet one of the exceptions. The persons are admitted to the territory of the country upon presentation of a valid EU digital COVID certificate for vaccination or illness or similar document, or a negative result from a polymerase chain reaction test for COVID-19 conducted up to 72 hours before entry into the country, certified by a valid EU digital COVID certificate for research or a similar document containing the same data as the EU digital COVID certificate for research.   Persons arriving from the following countries of the red zone are not allowed on the territory of the country: the Republic of Mozambique, the Republic of Botswana, the Republic of South Africa, Lesotho, Eswatini, the Republic of Namibia and the Republic of Zimbabwe, except for persons who are Bulgarian citizens and persons with status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria and the members of their families.  http://web.archive.org/web/20211219181539/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

A limit of 1,000 participants applies.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213102858/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213102858/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events

20 people can gather freely indoors or outdoors. When more than 20 people gather, they need to present a proof  of covid vaccination or recovery, and a limit of 100 people applies. Masks must be worn indoors  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213102858/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/culture/social-events
Masks must be worn while using public transport  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213103916/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/hygiene/means-transport
No stay at home requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227130850/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement
No restriction on internal movement  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227130850/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/free-movement-people/measures-free-movement

Different regulations applies to different countries. Most travelers must be tested. Travelers coming from a country listed as dark red must quarantine until they receive the results of their tests taken between 5 and 7 days after their arrival.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211022222537/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/foreigners/possibilities-and-obligations-foreigners-when-entering-cz

This compensation applies to cases where employees are ordered to quarantine or to be isolated due to COVID-19. The amount of the support is set at 80% of eligible costs (compensation of wages paid to employees + the corresponding amount of statutory contributions), but a maximum of CZK 39,000 per employee and month. For employees, this means that they are in obstacles and receive a wage compensation of 60% of average earnings.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213105600/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/compensation/antivirus-plus-forced-limitations-service-operation-and-quarantine
No change of policy found  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227132553/https://www.vlada.cz/en/media-centrum/aktualne/measures-adopted-by-the-czech-government-against-coronavirus-180545/
There is a government website to provide information  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213110225/https://covid.gov.cz/en/

Tests are available for all, they can be free of charge with a doctor request, paid for by the health insurance under certain conditions, or if none of the conditions apply, self-paid.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227172643/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/testing/how-get-tested

Self-reporting is recommended and tracing centers are organizing the tracing effort.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227172738/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/infection-and-general-measures/how-does-tracing-work
Masks are mandatory in most indoors public spaces.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211227173017/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/face-masks-and-respirators/indoors
Vaccines are available for all over 5 years old.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211213114103/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/register-vaccination/vaccination-nutshell

Some restrictions and protections still in place for people visiting elderly care facilities, such as pre-visit PCR/antigen testing or proof of vaccination.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211227173855/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/hospitals-and-sanitary-facilities/visits-social-facilities

Updated on 6 Dec 2021,  Vaccination against COVID-19 is:  VOLUNTARY  FREE (more precisely: paid by your health insurance carrier) - except for self-payers  only EMA-approved vaccines are used (more information about vaccines used)  currently, the amount of vaccines in our population is, unfortunately, not sufficient yet, thus, it is necessary to prioritize the doses (i.e., vulnerable population groups as elderly and those suffering under a chronic disease as well as essential infrastructure workers (medical workers, social workers, school staff, etc.) get vaccinated first)    https://archive.ph/mX12Z

Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to be tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 months. Two weekly test are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Corona passport is required at educational institutions such as universities, youth education and language schools    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212155303/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Children in primary school will be sent home from Wednesday 15 December 2021 until (and including) Tuesday 4 January 2022. Pupils in boarding schools and independent vocational schools will be sent home from Sunday 19 December 2021 to (and including) Friday 7 January 2021.    While in school, however, Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to get tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 6 months. Two weekly tests are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216151102/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

It is adviced to work at home extensively in both public and private workplaces and that meetings, seminars etc. are held virtually. It is adviced to cancel major social events at workplaces, including Christmas lunches. Municipal employers can require their employees to present a corona passport/COVID certificate. Employers may also, under certain conditions, require employees to be tested for corona and disclose the result of the test. However, employers must be able to objectively justify that a test is necessary to limit the spread of infection with COVID-19. Employees in the state and the regions will be required to present a corona passport/COVID certificate. A corona passport/COVID certificate when attending a conference, unless the organizer ensures that there are 100 or fewer spectators/participants indoors and 1,000 or fewer spectators/participants outdoors.    Discos, nightclubs and partybusses are closed, while bars must close at midnight.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212155303/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected must take a test before/within 24 hours after arrival.    2)  People coming in from areas with COVID-19 variants of concern within 10 days prior to the date of entering Denmark, must take a test within 24 hours of entry and immediately self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212160548/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected must take a test before/within 24 hours after arrival.    2)  People coming in from areas with COVID-19 variants of concern within 10 days prior to the date of entering Denmark, must take a test within 24 hours of entry and immediately self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival.       Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216152037/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

For people entering Denmark from an EU and / or Schengen country or COVID-19 risk country, there is no requirement for isolation after entry.    However, those entering from a COVID-19 high-risk country must self-isolate after entry, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected. The isolation is required for 10 days but the isolation may be ended after a negative PCR test taken at the earliest on the sixth day after the time of entry.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211231184528/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/covidtravelrules

1. Residents in nursing homes, assisted living, etc.    2. People aged = 65 who receive both personal care and practical assistance.    3. People aged = 85 years.    4. Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society.    5. Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19.    6. Selected relatives of individuals at significantly increased risk of a severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as caregivers.    7. People aged 80-84.    8. People aged 75-79.    9. People aged 65-74.    10 A. People aged 60-64 (born between 1957 and 1961).    10 B. People aged 55-59 (born between 1962 and 1966).    10 C. People aged 50-54 (born between 1967 and 1971).    10 D1. People aged 16-19 and 45-49 years (born 1972-1976 and 2002-2005).    10 D2. People aged 20-24 and 40-44 years (born 1977-1981 and 1997-2001).    10 D3. People aged 25-29 and 35-39 years (born 1982-1986 and 1992-1996).    10 D4. People aged 30-34 (born 1987-1991).    11. People aged 12-15 (born 2006-2009). Children, who turn 12 in 2021 will be invited by date of birth and as they turn 12.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202162815/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Vaccination%20against%20COVID-19/Who%20should%20be%20vaccinated

Facial coverings are required in all public spaces in Spain: https://web.archive.org/web/20211229212801/https://www.thelocal.es/20211227/reminder-what-are-the-rules-and-exceptions-for-wearing-face-masks-outdoors-in-spain/  There are a two exceptions: face masks are not considered necessary outdoors  âduring individual sportsâ (for example, going for a jog or a cycle on your own) or âduring activities that are not sporting in nature, but are carried out in natural spacesâ, such as hanging out at the beach or hiking in the forest.     These exceptions are contingent on the 1.5 metre social distancing rules being maintained.    The face mask can also be removed outdoors in Spain by those travelling by boat, an exception that was included in the previous law. However, the new rules make masks mandatory below deck, even if social distancing is maintained.    Face masks will not be mandatory inside residences, centres for people with disabilities, or similar homes, provided that the vaccination rate is 80 percent or higher with the full schedule and booster doses.    External visitors and workers at these centers are still required to wear face masks.

No changes in policy. *for future coding: Emergency meeting scheduled for 22 December, for possible new restrictions*  http://web.archive.org/web/20211220080343/https://www.thelocal.es/20211219/spanish-pm-sanchez-calls-for-new-measures-amid-real-risk-of-rising-covid-cases/

Extensive protection in place in Valencia region, with testing and COVID-19 certification requirements to visit care homes: https://web.archive.org/web/20211223155421/https://www.thelocal.es/20211223/explained-the-covid-restrictions-in-your-region-of-spain-this-christmas/
Masks and social distancing measures are recommended only, not mandatory.    https://archive.ph/ENcnK

Workplaces are open but the employers must evaluate the risks present in the working environment and enact measures to lower the risks: these measures can include requirement to wear a mask, testing, vaccination, re-organisation of work...    https://archive.ph/kFT6d

At entertainment public establishments indoors it is obligatory for all persons from the age of 12 years and three months to present a valid COVID certificate.  Protective mask is obligatory for all person from the age of 12 or above    https://archive.ph/OjDhC#content_q10068237

In public spaces, gathering requires Covid certificates for all people over 12. The restriction does not apply to private events in private places.  Limitations to the number of participants: Up to 1000 people may participate in events and activities indoors and up to 2000 people outdoors.  Events must end no later than at 23.00 (the restriction is temporarily suspended between December 31, 2021 and the morning of January 2, 2022)    https://archive.ph/OjDhC#content_q10068237
Masks must be worn in public transports for people over 12, but Covid certificates are not required.    https://archive.ph/ZspRN
There is no stay at home requirement.    https://archive.ph/toR7y
No restriction on internal movement is found.    https://archive.ph/toR7y

Depending on the country of origins, travelers may have to fill up a questionnaire, get tested or quarantine.   All travellers arriving from the risk countries of the Omicron strain or those who have been in the risk countries within the past 10 calendar days have to do a PCR test immediately after arriving in Estonia.     https://archive.ph/JVc1V
No income support provided, only sick days    https://archive.ph/goca3
No debt relief announced for households    https://archive.ph/goca3
There is an updated government website    https://archive.ph/toR7y

In most cases, family physicians or the Health Board must refer their patients to testing. Specific providers can also provide tests for a fee to anyone who wants to be tested.    https://archive.ph/ogvVw
Contact tracing is done through the HOIA app     https://archive.ph/DBH1z
A protective mask is obligatory in public indoor spaces (including rooms where COVID certificate is checked, e.g. cinema, theatre, events, trainings etc).     https://archive.ph/QyQ1S
In 2021, vaccination is free for everybody who lives in Estonia, over the age of 12.    https://archive.ph/7Zm9j
Recommendations of sanitary measures are made for visitors of care homes. There is also a policy that the care homes have to follow in case of suspicion of infection.     https://archive.ph/I5YGi
In 2021, vaccination is free for everybody who lives in Estonia, over the age of 12.    https://archive.ph/7Zm9j
In 2021, vaccination is free for everybody who lives in Estonia, over the age of 12. Vaccines are funded by government.    https://archive.ph/7Zm9j

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare has restricted all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529) from 27th November. Entry from these regions is also restricted and only allowed under certain circumstances.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212152923/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212153700/https://raja.fi/en/guidelines-for-border-traffic-during-pandemic

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017165013/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona

Testing is generally available but specificall recommended not only for those who are symptomatic, but also for those among these group who have been exposed to the virus: those who are unvaccinated, those have received only one vaccine dose of a series of two doses, those are fully vaccinated but less than a week has elapsed since the second dose of the vaccine and have been exposed to coronavirus within the last two weeks, and those who belong to a group for which a third dose of vaccine is recommended, but you have not yet received a third dose. A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210820141655/https://koronavilkku.fi/en

The Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare recommends that COVID-19 vaccinations are offered to different groups in the following order:    1. Health care personnel caring for COVID-19 patients, personnel and residents in round-the-clock care units, other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care, and election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting  1.1. Personnel in intensive care units    1.2. Personnel in hospital wards and emergency care for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients    1.3. Personnel at facilities for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients, coronavirus testing personnel, and laboratory personnel involved in coronavirus diagnostics    1.4. Personnel and residents in social services for residential care and enhanced institutional, round-the-clock care units    1.5. Other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care    In group 1.5, a limited number of social welfare and health care personnel working in functions that are considered urgent and critical by the region can be vaccinated against COVID-19. These functions are essential for guaranteeing the patientsâ statutory right to urgent treatment.    Such groups of essential personnel include:    Acute psychiatry unit personnel  Essential staff for units providing urgent care (such as round-the-clock emergency clinics and daytime emergency clinics)  Surgical and operative unit personnel providing emergency or urgent care  Personnel providing emergency or urgent care at wards  Personnel dealing with births  Personnel at emergency social work for substance abuse   Personnel at emergency services for child welfare  1.6. Election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting    As of 19 April 2021, according to an amendment to the Government decree, the election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting in the 2021 municipal elections will be treated as section 1 of the vaccination order.    This group includes the chairpersons, vice-chairpersons, members and deputy members of the electoral committees referred to in section 15 of the Election Act (714/1998) and the electoral commissioners responsible for at-home voting referred to in section 17.    Election boards are not included in this group.    2. The elderly, and persons with underlying conditions that predispose to severe COVID-19  Elderly persons are at the greatest risk for severe COVID-19 disease. Certain underlying conditions also predispose to severe COVID-19.    2.1. = 80-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*                  2.2. 75â79-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*    2.3. 70â74-year-olds, and carers living in the same household    2.4. 12â69-year-olds with a highly predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    2.5. 12â69-year-olds with a predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    * When vaccinating persons aged 70 or over, all those aged 70 or over living in the same household can be vaccinated at the same time when the oldest member of the household is eligible for vaccination, if this is feasible with regard to practical arrangements.    THL recommends that persons in terminal care should not be vaccinated. A decision on the vaccination of persons with fragile health is always made on a case-by-case basis in cooperation with the treating physician, the person being vaccinated and their family members.    Coronavirus vaccination order for risk groups    Press release 5.2.2021: THL has detailed medical risk groups for coronavirus vaccines     3. Others  According to a Government decree that entered into force on 19 April 2021, the rest of the population will be vaccinated by age group starting from the oldest age group.    3.1. 60â69-year-olds    3.2. 50â59-year-olds    3.3. 40â49-year-olds    3.4. 30â39-year-olds    3.5. 16â29-year-olds    3.5. 12â15-year-olds    Social welfare and health care personnel not included in groups 1.1â1.5 are vaccinated based on age along with the rest of the population.     Children under the age of 12 are not yet vaccinated, as no coronavirus vaccine in use has yet been authorised for children under that age.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202170308/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19

No change in policy    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212154240/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19

No change in policy    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145900/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19

Personnel at facilities for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients, coronavirus testing personnel, and laboratory personnel involved in coronavirus diagnostics    1.4. Personnel and residents in social services for residential care and enhanced institutional, round-the-clock care units    1.5. Other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care    In group 1.5, a limited number of social welfare and health care personnel working in functions that are considered urgent and critical by the region can be vaccinated against COVID-19. These functions are essential for guaranteeing the patientsâ statutory right to urgent treatment.    Such groups of essential personnel include:    Acute psychiatry unit personnel  Essential staff for units providing urgent care (such as round-the-clock emergency clinics and daytime emergency clinics)  Surgical and operative unit personnel providing emergency or urgent care  Personnel providing emergency or urgent care at wards  Personnel dealing with births  Personnel at emergency social work for substance abuse   Personnel at emergency services for child welfare  1.6. Election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting    As of 19 April 2021, according to an amendment to the Government decree, the election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting in the 2021 municipal elections will be treated as section 1 of the vaccination order.    This group includes the chairpersons, vice-chairpersons, members and deputy members of the electoral committees referred to in section 15 of the Election Act (714/1998) and the electoral commissioners responsible for at-home voting referred to in section 17.    Election boards are not included in this group.    2. The elderly, and persons with underlying conditions that predispose to severe COVID-19  Elderly persons are at the greatest risk for severe COVID-19 disease. Certain underlying conditions also predispose to severe COVID-19.    2.1. = 80-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*                  2.2. 75â79-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*    2.3. 70â74-year-olds, and carers living in the same household    2.4. 12â69-year-olds with a highly predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    2.5. 12â69-year-olds with a predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    * When vaccinating persons aged 70 or over, all those aged 70 or over living in the same household can be vaccinated at the same time when the oldest member of the household is eligible for vaccination, if this is feasible with regard to practical arrangements.    THL recommends that persons in terminal care should not be vaccinated. A decision on the vaccination of persons with fragile health is always made on a case-by-case basis in cooperation with the treating physician, the person being vaccinated and their family members.    Coronavirus vaccination order for risk groups    Press release 5.2.2021: THL has detailed medical risk groups for coronavirus vaccines     3. Others  According to a Government decree that entered into force on 19 April 2021, the rest of the population will be vaccinated by age group starting from the oldest age group.    3.1. 60â69-year-olds    3.2. 50â59-year-olds    3.3. 40â49-year-olds    3.4. 30â39-year-olds    3.5. 16â29-year-olds    3.5. 12â15-year-olds    Social welfare and health care personnel not included in groups 1.1â1.5 are vaccinated based on age along with the rest of the population.     Children under the age of 12 are not yet vaccinated, as no coronavirus vaccine in use has yet been authorised for children under that age. The third vaccine dose is now recommended to anyone above the age of 18      Archived: https://archive.vn/I4JbZ

No change in policy, all schools remain at the Level 2/Yellow level introduced on 15 November, irrespective of the incidence rate of Covid-19 in the local population. https://web.archive.org/web/20211205060819/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

From 9 December, all primary schools are moved to Level 3/Orage level restrictions; facial coverings are required in playgrounds and contact sports are restricted. Masks continue to be required when inside for all staff and students aged 6 and over. https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185154/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change to the policy implemented on 9 December: all primary schools are moved to Level 3/Orage level restrictions; facial coverings are required in playgrounds and contact sports are restricted. Masks continue to be required when inside for all staff and students aged 6 and over. Classes will be closed and learning moved online if there are more than 3 cases of COVID-19 in a particular class. In universities, barrier protection is required, masks are mandatory, and student who test positive and their contacts must self-isolate for 7 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182600/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075403/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus and  https://web.archive.org/web/20211126150822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to many workplaces by both employees and customers. From 9 December, discotheques are to be closed for a period of at least 4 weeks. The government recommends that 2 or 3 days per week of remote working are implemented in work environments where teleworking is possible, face-to-face meetings should be limited, and welcome and leaving ceremonies should be postponed.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20211207210635/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  - https://web.archive.org/web/20211209195104/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to many workplaces by both employees and customers. From 9 December, discotheques are to be closed until 6 January 2022, mand dancing in restaurants and bars is prohibited until the same date. The government recommends that 2 or 3 days per week of remote working are implemented in work environments where teleworking is possible, face-to-face meetings should be limited, and welcome and leaving ceremonies should be postponed.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20211222062141/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
Use of the Health Pass continues to be required for access to public events. https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185255/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is required to access almost all public events. Prefects in all Departments are authorized to prohibit public events and gatherings, consumption of alcohol in public places, and are recommended to prohibit public events including fireworks and concerts where barrier methods cannot be implemented. https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to access many places or events where people gather, and these rules have applied since 21 July to access places of leisure and culture (including concert halls, amusement parks, concert halls, festivals, sports halls, games rooms, libraries and documentation centres, or cinemas), and have been extended since 9 August to cover:    - commercial catering activities (bars and restaurants, including on terraces), with the exception of collective catering or take-away of prepared meals, professional road and rail catering, room service in hotel restaurants and bars and non-commercial catering, including the free distribution of meals;  - trade fairs and exhibitions, and professional seminars;  - health, social and medico-social services and institutions, for persons accompanying or visiting persons accommodated in such services and establishments as well as for those who are accommodated there for scheduled care. This measure, which applies subject to emergency cases, does not have the effect of limiting access to care;  - long-distance travel by interregional public transport (domestic flights, TGV journeys, IntercitÃ©s and night trains, interregional coaches);  - department stores and shopping centers of more than 20,000mÂ²,by decision of the prefect of the department, when their characteristics and the seriousness of the risks of contamination justify it, under conditions guaranteeing access to people to essential goods and services as well as to the means of transport accessible within the walls of these stores and centers. Currently, shopping centers of more than 20,000 mÂ² located in departments under strong epidemic pressure are subject to the "health pass" after decision of the prefects concerned;  - ski lifts and Christmas markets (unless the prefect decides otherwise);  - access to tourist accommodation such as campsites or holiday clubs is subject to the "health pass", with a single control at the beginning of the stay;  - prefects have the possibility of making the "health pass" mandatory in places of gathering or on the occasion of events,such as markets for example.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182727/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire    The government discourages private holiday gatherings, recommends avoiding kissing, and avoiding large gatherings of people (although there is no evidence of rules enfocing such behaviour) - https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Public transport is available throughout France, but access to long-distance travel on public transport requires use of the Health Pass. https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185255/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Local transport remains open without restriction, use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance and inter-regional travel on buses, trains and airplanes - https://web.archive.org/web/20211226182727/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
There are no stay-at-home requirements in metropolitan France - https://web.archive.org/web/20211215193401/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No requirements to stay at home are in place - https://web.archive.org/web/20211224033327/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
Use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance journeys on any form of public transport - https://web.archive.org/web/20211217001806/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

From 4 December at midnight, any person entering French territory from a country outside the European area must present a negative PCR or antigen test of less than 48 hours. The time for antigen tests for travel from scarlet red countries is 24 hours (see below).    "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, the Comoros, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.    As a precautionary measure, and pending additional data on the Omicron variant, a category of "scarlet red" countries is created: particularly active circulation of the virus and/or discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape. These are: Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    The ability to travel from or to French territory depends on this classification and the vaccination status of travelers, for complete details see https://web.archive.org/web/20211204173746/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 12 December, the classification of countries is as follows:     Green: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, the Comoros, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.  Orange: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.  Red: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Mauritius, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.  Scarlet Red:  countries/territories in which a particularly active circulation of the virus is observed and/or the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape. These are: Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    Details of the travel controls imposed per category are contained at https://web.archive.org/web/20211217002052/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 00:00 on 18 December, new rules impact travel between the United Kingdom and France due to prevalence of the Omicron variant in the UK. All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of vaccination status, from the United Kingdom:    - are subject to the regime of compelling reasons,the list of which is specified in the certificate of travel and travel drawn up by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France and return to their residence in the United Kingdom: french people and their spouses and children;  - must present a negative PCR or antigen (TAG) test taken less than 24 hours before flight boarding;  - must register before departure on the eOS-COVID digital platform  (https://web.archive.org/web/20211202154207/https://passager.serveureos.org/);  - may be subject to an antigen test on arrival;  - will be subject to mandatory isolation for 10 days, supervised and controlled by the security forces. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to a negative PCR or antigen test.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20211218000501/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/royaume-uni/    Restrictions for travelers from other countries remain as per the update of 12 December - https://web.archive.org/web/20211217002052/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

No change in policy, vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and 2 months. The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France. https://web.archive.org/web/20211204191348/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and 2 months. vaccination booster is open to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211207123504/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and two months. From 15 December, vaccination is available to children aged between 5 and 11 who are overweight or who have an underlying medical condition.     Vaccination booster is open to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have made their recall, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211207123504/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224120928/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

From 22 December, vaccination is universally available to people aged over 5 years and older.    Vaccination booster is available to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection and one month after the second injection, or five months after recovery from infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received their booster vaccination, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over with mobility issues are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224120928/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075648/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass have changed for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.     For people aged over 80 years of age who have mobility issues and wish to benefit from a vaccination at home can access a special toll-free number to put them in touch with services likely to offer them a vaccination at home.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185817/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

The UK is removing all countries from its red travel list, just weeks after reactivating the list in response to the new Omicron variant.    As of tomorrow, 15 December, people arriving from 11 African countries will no longer need to stay in one of the government-run quarantine hotels.    People currently in a UK quarantine hotel will also be allowed to leave early, as long as they do not test positive for COVID-19.    However all current testing requirements will remain in place, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps confirmed on Twitter this afternoon.    he UK recently updated its travel rules, stipulating that all arrivals must now show a negative pre-departure PCR or lateral flow test that was taken within 48 hours of arriving.    This is in addition to a day 2 PCR test, which both UK citizens and visitors must await the results of in isolation. The rules vary for unvaccinated travellers.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211215095343/https://www.euronews.com/travel/2021/12/14/uk-travel-all-countries-removed-from-the-uk-s-red-quarantine-list

Cancel Public Events C3 - 2G  As of December 1, Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types, and similar. Night clubs remain banned. entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned.  Sports tournaments of various types may be held without spectators.   https://archive.vn/6iW0Bhttps://archive.vn/6iW0B

On December 1, cinema and theater attendances will grow from 30% to 50%. On December 1, restrictions on restaurant opening hours will be lifted. The ban on concerts and festivals is removed so long as applicable regulations are observed. Restriction remains valid on holding the wide-scale entertainment and such social events, as wedding parties, banquets, jubilees of various types and similar. Eateries and ritual venues of miscellaneous types will be sanctioned with 10 000 GEL for hosting such events but will be sealed if found in breach of the regulation for the second time.   Also, camping of any type is banned, regardless of the organizational form or venue.   Any type of entertainment activities, arts and culture events (except for stage performances and cinema), festivals are going to be fully banned. The referred restriction does not apply to concerts to be held at the premises of hotels. As for sports tournaments of various types, they may be held without spectators. Nevertheless, every participant should be vaccinated (14 days should be lapsed from the second dose) or have a PCR test result obtained in the past 72 hours or a negative result of an antigen test obtained in the past 24 hours.  Amendments have been made to Government Resolution N322 dated May 23, 2020 on the Adoption of the Rules of Isolation and Quarantine, according to which delegates will be allowed to attend conferences, trainings and seminars from July 19, 2021 only with a negative PCR test taken 72 hours prior or express antigen test taken 24 hours prior to the event and/or without the latter on the 14th day from full vaccination.   Source: https://archive.vn/qcOkW

Republic of South Africa  Republic of Botswana  Republic of Zimbabwe  Republic of Namibia  Kingdom of Lesotho  Kingdom of Eswatini (Swaziland)  Republic of Mozambique  Republic of Malawi  Source: https://archive.vn/EohxU.

no policy change     At level 4 (red) of the Epidemiology Charter country incorporated the Regional Units Kavala, Imathia, Pieria and Pella , while extending a special, local, measures in Regional Units Haryana and Argolis , after re-evaluation of epidemiological data the Committee of Infectious Diseases and the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against the Covid-19 coronavirus in the context of the epidemiological surveillance of the country by Regional Unit and Municipality on a weekly basis.    At the same time, level 3 (orange) includes the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion , as well as the Municipality of Ikaria .    It is reminded that the measures in force are the following:    Traffic ban from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in stores of health interest and entertainment.  The measures are valid from tomorrow, Friday 17 September at 06.00 until Friday 24 September at 6:00 .    It is also reminded that in these areas, as well as in the whole territory, it is forbidden to hold any form of events in exchange for any form of exchange, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space . The administrative fine in case of violation amounts from 50,000 to 200,000 euros for the lessee or concessionaire of the private, non-professional space, in which the said event took place or takes place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210919221253/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-kavala-imathia-pieria-kai-pella

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

In Greenland, there is a requirement for vaccination against COVID-19 or a negative PCR test, which is a maximum of 48 hours old, for people who want to stay in premises and associated areas with public access.  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have a negative PCR test that is a maximum of 48 hours old:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments and their adjoining outdoor areas.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor and outdoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212155747/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

In Greenland, there is a requirement for vaccination against COVID-19 or a negative PCR test, which is a maximum of 48 hours old, for people who want to stay in premises and associated areas with public access.  -The requirement applies to citizens over 12 years of age.  -You must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have a negative test  -You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have a negative PCR test that is a maximum of 48 hours old:  1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments and their adjoining outdoor areas.  2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc.  3) Community centres and similar establishments.  4) Libraries.  5) Indoor and outdoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc.  6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments.    When are you fully vaccinated?  -People who have completed a full vaccination programme, for example two doses of Pfizer or Moderna vaccine or one dose of Johnson&Johnson vaccine, are considered fully vaccinated. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 and can present documentation of a positive PCR test result which is between 14 days and 12 weeks old, you are covered by the same rules as if you were fully vaccinated.  *updated definition of being fully vaccinated  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228235327/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/

Public transportation is open but depending on the vaccination status in relation to domestic travel in Greenland.    -If you travel from a city or settlement to another place within the countryâs borders, you must be fully vaccinated or have a negative test that is no more than 48 hours old at the time of departure.  -The owner of the means of transportation is responsible for ensuring that all travellers obey the rules.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212160622/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

Public transportation is open but depending on the vaccination status in relation to domestic travel in Greenland.    -If you travel from a city or settlement to another place within the countryâs borders, you must be fully vaccinated or have a negative test that is no more than 48 hours old at the time of departure. This also applies if you have a stopover in Greenland, e.g. in Kangerlussuaq, before you travel out of the country.  -The owner of the means of transportation is responsible for ensuring that all travellers obey the rules.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211229000442/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

Domestic travel in Greenland:  -If you travel from a city or settlement to another place within the countryâs borders, you must be fully vaccinated or have a negative test that is no more than 48 hours old at the time of departure.  -The owner of the means of transportation is responsible for ensuring that all travellers obey the rules.  -Unvaccinated people over the age of 2 years old traveling out of a city or settlement where it is not possible to be tested must quarantine at their destination for 14 days, or until they get a negative PCR test. If it is not possible to get a PCR test at the destination, they must quarantine for 14 days.  -If you are in quarantine, you are not allowed to attend events or gatherings. You may go and get tested and go to grocery stores to make necessary purchases if you wear face masks or visors.  -Children under the age of 2 are exempt from the requirement of showing documentation of a test.  -If you have previously been infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 weeks, and you are able to document this, the same rules apply to you as to fully vaccinated people.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212160622/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

Updated policy for 'Travel from a place where you canât get tested â no spread of infection' for 'Unvaccinated 12 yrs old or older' from 'Test Requirement (<48 hours)' to 'Quarantine upon Arrival'.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211220212138/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/domestic-travel-in-greenland/

*Changed PCR swab tests validity from maximum 72 hrs to maximum 48 hrs old    Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland. In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after your last dose.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206211801/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated or a resident of Greenland or you are relocating to Greenland.    -In regard to entering Greenland, you are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. This means that for the time being there is no requirement to get the booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated.    When you intend to travel to Greenland, you must remember to do the following:  -You must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test from a Nordic country (Denmark, Sweden, Norway, Finland, Iceland, Faroe Islands), UK, Liechtenstein, Switzerland, or a country in EU that is maximum 48 hours old from the time of departure and have valid documentation showing this.  -Bring a face mask for the journey and wear it during the journey, on the plane and in the airport, and also during transport to your place of residence. This rule applies to everyone at 12 years old or older.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220215011/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Face masks can be used as a supplement for preventing the spread of infection in situations where it is difficult to keep to distance. It is important that you continue to follow the advice relating to keeping a distance and good hygiene even when you wear a face mask.    In Greenland, you must wear a face mask in the following situations:  -When you are in premises with public access in cities and settlements with a current spread of infection with COVID-19. Find the list of cities and settlements with current spread of infection in Area restrictions.  -All individuals aged 12 years or older on domestic or international flights (face masks must be worn to the quarantine location/end destination).  -If you have been infected or risk of being infected with COVID-19 and in exceptional circumstances must move outside, e.g. because you need to get tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206143427/https://corona.nun.gl/en/prevention/use-of-face-masks-and-visors/

Fines for Non-Compliance:  Health Inspectors of the Croatian State Inspectorate are monitoring and enforcing individual orders to self-isolate. They are authorized to fine any individual violating this order with fines ranging from 8000 HRK for the first violation to 30,000 HRK, 60,000 HRK and 120,000 HRK for repeat offenders. Persons violating health inspector orders may also be subject to criminal charges.  People caught not wearing a mask (or improperly wearing a mask) in mask-designated areas will be fined 500 HRK, but they will be eligible to pay half that amount (250 HRK) if they agree to put on a mask immediately.  Legal entities will be fined 10,000-40,000 HRK if they do not respect the epidemiological measures related to public gatherings.  Businesses will be fined 5,000-10,000 HRK for not implementing epidemiological measures.  Passengers in transit (individuals in transit have 12 hours to exit the country, and they must show that they can enter or transit through the neighboring country). Fines in violation of this provision range from 5,000 to 10,000 HRK.    Restrictions for Individuals and Businesses  Businesses and individuals may be restricted due to the epidemiological measures based on your location in Croatia. Most notable epidemiological restrictions may include a requirement to wear a mask indoors unless seated in a restaurant or coffee shop. Venues hosting larger audiences may require visitors to present a negative COVID-19 test or record of vaccination. Some venues like night clubs or concert halls offer onsite rapid testing services for a fee. Wedding parties of up to 120 guests are permitted with a mandate that all guests, staff, and entertainers must have been vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19 or have a negative viral test.    Individual counties and cities may have additional measures. Please visit?the?Croatian Governmentâs COVID-19 website?for additional information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206183854/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On Wednesday, December 15, 2021, the Croatian Parliament amended the Law on the Protection of the Population from Infectious Diseases. It introduces fines of 30 to 50 thousand kuna for responsible persons who do not respect the obligation to present covid certificates in public law bodies.    On the same day, the Civil Protection Headquarters of the Republic of Croatia made seven new decisions that are valid from 16 December to 31 December this year, when they will be considered again. The Headquarters extended the Decision on the introduction of a special security measure in the social welfare sector.    The decision implies âmandatory testing of all employees for the SARS-CoV-2 virus in the social welfare activity, ie in social welfare institutions, associations, religious communities, other legal entities, craftsmen and natural persons who perform social welfare as a professional activity and the Center for Social Welfare. special guardianship, who come to work at least twice in seven days. ". Exceptionally, testing is not mandatory for employees who "qualify for vaccination or recovery from COVID-19 unless they have signs of respiratory infection, other symptoms, or signs of COVID-19 infectious disease."    Recall, from mid-November this year, covid-certificates are mandatory for all employees of public and state services, as well as users of their services.    The same decision applies to all parties who come there, all service providers who provide services in those premises or other persons who come there on any grounds. Those who refuse to present a certificate cannot enter the premises.    The EU digital covid-certification system has been developed at the level of the European Union, and 42 countries are participating in it.    https://www.koronavirus.hr/produzuje-se-vecina-covid-mjera-uvedene-velike-kazne-za-nepostivanje-predocenja-covid-potvrda/1002
No change in prior policy, as measures last till end of 2021

Non-Hungarian nationals may enter the territory of Hungary only in exceptional cases, and exemption to the rules of entry may only be granted by the appropriate police agency at the point of entry into Hungary, or at the 18th District Police Station of the Budapest Police Headquarters upon entry at Budapest Liszt Ferenc International Airport.    The police agency may authorise entry if the applicant proves that the purpose of entry is:  1. participation in a procedural step of a Hungarian judicial or administrative procedure, proven with an instrument issued by a Hungarian court or authority,  2. receipt of health care with the referral of a health institution or other appropriate proof,  3. a study or examination obligation based on student or pupil status, if proven with a certificate issued by the educational institution,  4. passenger travel related to work associated with forwarding, the purpose of which is travel to the point of departure of the forwarding assignment (location for starting work), or return home by passenger travel after said work, if proven with the certificate issued by the employer,  5. participation in family events (marriage, baptism, funeral),  6. caring for or nursing a relative in accordance with Act V of 2013 of the Civil Code,  7. participation in an international, major religious event, or  8. other equitable grounds.    The passenger may be granted exemption from quarantine, if they present two negative tests in conformity with professional medical regulations within 5 days, with at least 48 hours difference between the tests. In this case, this test shall be considered a first test if it was conducted in a range of countries.    All the rules do not apply if the person is double vaccinated, holds an immunity certificate or has a negative PCR-Test that is not older than 72 hours from a range of countries. Also, the rules do not apply if the person enters the country from a neighbouring country excluding civilian aircrafts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217142936/https://visithungary.com/articles/entry-rules-in-force
No policy changes.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217134702/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

At indoor cultural and other events, gyms, swimming pools, spas, and   catering shops, employees must wear a mask . In crÃ¨ches, kindergartens, schools, principals and in higher education institutions, rectors, and in other workplaces, employers can determine the rules for wearing a mask. Events of more than 500 people can only be attended with a security card.  Hospitals have been banned from visiting.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211217134702/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

All guests are seated and not facing each other  1 meter social distancing between guests  All attendees were a mask.  Alcoholic beverages are not sold before, during or after event. Three types of COVID-tests are in use. PCR-tests are used by the health care system to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, and when people might be infected. Rapid antigen tests are also used in the health care system and by certified test centers, both before events, but also at the beginning and end of special precaution.
