You quarantine if:  You've been in a relationship with someone who turned out to be infected.  You are traveling abroad and do not have a vaccination certificate or previous COVID-19 infection.  You do not quarantine if:  You've been with someone who was later quarantined.  Your neighbor is infected (for example, in the same stairwell), unless you have been in a lot of contact.  Quarantine ends:  Quarantine can be shortened to 5 days if you go for sampling, otherwise quarantine is 14 days.  You will automatically receive a barcode for the sampling, you do not need to register specifically for it.  A quarantine that takes place in a home where someone is in isolation ends with a negative result from sampling after the isolation has been lifted. Households can then expect a quarantine day longer than isolation lasts. In order to fulfill the conditions for shortening the quarantine to 5 days, there must be a complete separation between the person in isolation and the person in the quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220222329/https://www.covid.is/undirflokkar/sottkvi
There is no information available on contact tracing

Face masks must be worn wherever the 1 meter social distancing rule cannot be observed between people who are unrelated. Mask obligation does not apply to children born 2006 or later.  Face masks must be used where it is not possible to ensure 1 metre of social distancing, such as in healthcare services, shops, museums, domestic flights and ferries, public transport, taxis and coaches, in practical driving lessons and flight training, hairdressers, beauty salons, massage parlours, tattoo parlours, dog grooming salons, tanning salons and other similar activities.  Those who do not have the understanding or maturity to use a face mask correctly or are unable to do so for other reasons, such as health reasons, do not have to wear a mask.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220170132/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions
Face masks must be worn wherever the 2 metre social distancing rule cannot be observed between people who are unrelated.  https://archive.ph/Zcxrx

no changes in policy, green passes are still required for university students.    Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    Starting Dec 6th a vaccine mandate is in place for all school personnel.   University students still need to hold a green pass to attend lessons in presence.  Some confusion is spreading for all students age 12+ as for people 12+ it is mandatory to hold a green pass for taking public transport, and school transport is not an exception. Ongoing discussions to avoid enforcement of such law for people <18 years old.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211210170128/https://www.wired.it/article/green-pass-scuola-universita-regole-vaccino-mezzi/  http://web.archive.org/web/20211126180905/https://www.orizzontescuola.it/green-pass-per-studenti-over-12-che-si-recano-a-scuola-con-i-mezzi-pubblici-tanti-i-dubbi/  http://web.archive.org/web/20211207075547/https://tg24.sky.it/cronaca/2021/12/07/green-pass-studenti-trasporti

quote: "Kazakhstan will tighten international entry restrictions from Dec. 3 over concerns regarding the recently identified Omicron variant of COVID-19. From this date, nonresident foreign nationals from the following countries are prohibited from entry: South Africa, Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Madagascar, eSwatini, Malawi, Tanzania, and Hong Kong. Additionally, travelers from countries that have declared the presence of the Omicron variant must - regardless of vaccination status - present a negative PCR test and self-isolate for seven days on arrival; these countries currently include Australia, Belgium, the UK, Czech Republic, Germany, Egypt, Israel, Italy, Canada, and the Netherlands."    Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20211220054019/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50

According to the Liechtenstein tourism website, last updated on 16 Dec 2021:   - "There will be a general obligation to wear masks in all indoor areas from 26 November 2021."   - "The obligation to wear a mask applies in principle from the age of 6 (from 18 December)."   - "Masks are compulsory in institutions open to the public. This does not apply to children before their 6th birthday, persons who cannot wear a face mask for medical reasons, pupils during lessons at primary level and children in institutions providing supplementary childcare."    Liechtenstein tourism website  https://archive.vn/9vgPt

Schools are open but masks must be worn indoors. Contrat service will be provided in schools. In higher education, the national certificate (covid passport) is required, or students have to get tested every 7-10 days.    https://archive.ph/t5uyH

We can find no recommendation for workplaces to remain closed  As of 1 October, face masks are again required indoors (in trade and service provision points, institutions, companies, or organizations, at work and in education, during events, etc.), regardless of vaccination status.    https://archive.ph/t5uyH

Access to indoor events is banned for people without a National Certificate (Covid passport). They are not allowed to access indoor events, and outdoor events that have more than 500 attendees.     https://archive.ph/t5uyH

People without a National Certificate are banned from attending outdoor events of more than 500 people.  Access to indoor events is banned for people without a National Certificate (Covid passport).    https://archive.ph/t5uyH

There is no stay at home requirement.    https://archive.ph/t5uyH

PE classes are held in accordance with current health measures  Masks must be worn during sports activities  School swimming lessons are suspended  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221134119/https://covid19.mc/en/the-sanitary-measures-in-force/

Everyone will have to show their health pass to drink inside and on the terraces of restaurants and bars. This also applies to young people aged 16 to 18   The health pass will also be required for access to theatres and congresses when there are more than 300 people.  Booking is required in restaurants and there is maximum of 12 people per table (seated service)  There must be a distance between tables in restaurants of at least 1 metre on the terrace and inside  For customers, wearing a mask will be required in the queue. However, it will no longer be compulsory inside the establishment  Standing consumption is not allowed  In sports halls, auditoriums or congress halls, the public capacity is increased from 70% to 100% of the seats, an exemption being possible on presentation of a specific health protocol  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221134119/https://covid19.mc/en/the-sanitary-measures-in-force/
See note C4.Health Pass is required for some sectors. https://archive.vn/PuWwS https://archive.ph/TN4nh

The Government has set up a National Screening Center. It is located on the ground floor of the Rainier III Auditorium.    The aim is to regulate and co-ordinate PCR testing in order to optimise the time taken to obtain results.    This screening center welcomes any Monegasque, Monegasque resident or insured in Monaco or any student educated in Monaco, with the obligation to make an appointment in advance by calling the call center 92055500.  https://archive.fo/D7LF5  http://web.archive.org/web/20211221134119/https://covid19.mc/en/the-sanitary-measures-in-force/

The Government of Monaco is proposing a "3rd dose" to Monegasques and residents aged 65 and over as well as health professionals provided that they have received the last dose of vaccine against Covid-19 more than six months ago. Additionally it is recommended for people who have a neutralising antibody level of less than 30% (the 6-month delay since the last dose is not required) and people with medical conditions, provided they have a medical certificate (the 6-month period since the last dose is not required).  https://archive.vn/VI1Uq
Any person aged 5 and over, whether a Monegasque, resident or a pupil/student attending school or working in Monaco, can receive the vaccine free of charge. https://archive.ph/0McUG

"Daycare centres for children aged 0 to 4 are open.  From Monday 20 December to Friday 24 December primary schools and schools for special primary education will be closed. Out-of-school care facilities (BSO) will also be closed during this week.    Schools will be open to provide emergency care for vulnerable children and the children of key workers in crucial sectors.   Schools that are unable to put this emergency care into place in time must close no later than Tuesday 21 December, as must out-of-school care facilities.   Primary schools are open.  All staff and pupils in primary years 6, 7 and 8 are advised to do a self-test twice a week. This also applies to staff and pupils who are vaccinated or have had coronavirus.   Pupils and staff with symptoms, including mild cold symptoms, must stay at home and get tested by the municipal health service (GGD) or do a self-test.  Staff must wear a face mask when moving around the school, for example, in hallways. Face masks may be taken off in the classroom. Children in primary years 6, 7 and 8 are encouraged to wear a face mask outside their classroom.  Secondary schools are open.  Pupils and staff are advised to do a self-test at home twice a week. This also applies to staff and pupils who are vaccinated or have had coronavirus.  Pupils and staff with symptoms must stay at home and get tested by the municipal health service (GGD) or do a self-test.  All pupils and staff must wear a face mask when moving around the school, for example in hallways. Face masks may be taken off in the classroom  Secondary vocational schools (mbo) are open.  Higher education institutions (hbo and universities) are open.  Accredited (further) education may take place in the evenings."    https://archive.fo/YPWlL

"The special entry restrictions that were introduced for travellers arriving from 8 countries in Southern Africa at the end of November will be removed. The measures were introduced to limit and delay the spread of the Omicron variant. The Norwegian Government is keeping the strict general entry restrictions that apply to arrival in Norway.  âOmicron is now established in many countries, including Norway. The Norwegian Directorate of Health and the Norwegian Institute of Public Health believe that it is no longer expedient to keep specific measures that target travellers from these 8 countries. This is why the special measures are being removed. We are also keeping the strict general entry restrictions that apply to arrival in Norway,â says Minister of Health and Care Services Ingvild Kjerkol.  The special measures targeted travellers arriving from South Africa, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Lesotho, Eswatini, and Malawi, where the virus variant was discovered. The change will enter into effect on 22 December at 12 am."    "Measures that will be kept  The strict general entry measures that apply to arrival in Norway will be kept. They include:  a requirement of entry registration for all travellers;    a general requirement for all travellers to get tested upon arrival in Norway;    a requirement of documentation of a negative test taken before arrival for people who cannot produce a verifiable COVID-19 certificate showing that they are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 during the past 6 months;    travel quarantine for people who arrive from a country that triggers a duty to quarantine and who cannot produce a verifiable COVID-19 certificate showing that they are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 during the past 6 months."  https://archive.fo/upo3s#selection-1393.1-1427.243

"Mandatory use of face coverings when it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 1 meter in shops, shopping centres, venues that serve food or alcohol, public transport, indoor station areas, and taxis. The duty to wear a face covering does not apply to children under the age of 12, or to those who are unable to wear a face covering for medical or other reasons.    People are also recommended to wear a face covering in places where there are many people and it is difficult to keep a distance â for example at the cloakroom after attending an event or when you are in a crowd leaving a football stadium. The duty to wear a face covering does not apply while sitting in designated seating or at a table in a venue that serves food or alcohol." "A requirement to wear a face covering when it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 1 metre in shops, shopping centres, venues that serve food or alcohol, public transport, taxis, and indoor station areas. The requirement also applies to employees unless physical barriers have been put in place.  The requirement to wear a face covering also applies to hairdressers, skin care professionals, and other businesses with one-to-one contact.  There is already a national recommendation in place to wear a face covering in places where there are many people and it is difficult to keep a distance â for example at the cloakroom after attending an event or when you are in a crowd leaving a football stadium."    http://web.archive.org/web/20211217164307/https://www.regjeringen.no/en/aktuelt/new-national-measures-to-keep-the-pandemic-under-control/id2891395/

"A requirement to wear a face covering when it is not possible to keep a distance of at least 1 metre in shops, shopping centres, venues that serve food or alcohol, public transport, taxis, and indoor station areas. The requirement also applies to employees unless physical barriers have been put in place.  The requirement to wear a face covering also applies to hairdressers, skin care professionals, and other businesses with one-to-one contact.  The requirement to wear a face covering also applies to indoor events, libraries, and museums. (new)  The requirement to wear a face covering does not apply when sitting at a table in a venue that serves food or alcohol (currently in force) or when eating or drinking while seated. 10/12/21  COVERING YOUR MOUTH AND NOSE ONLY WITH A MASK IN PUBLIC SPACES    It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose in such places as:    in buses, trams and trains,  in shops, malls, banks, markets and post offices  in cinemas and theatres,  at physicianâs offices, in outpatient clinics and hospitals, in massage and tattoo parlours  in churches, at schools and universities,  In government offices (when going there to take care of certain matters) and other civic centres.    https://archive.fo/wS5eU    From 20 December 2021 to 9 January 2022, all primary and secondary school students will switch to remote learning. Nurseries and kindergartens will operate without any change.

From 20 December 2021 to 9 January 2022, all primary and secondary school students will switch to remote learning. Nurseries and kindergartens will operate without any change.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  From 1.11, the obligation to cover the mouth and nose will be introduced in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.    https://archive.fo/J3kN7

The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  From 1.11, the obligation to cover the mouth and nose will be introduced in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     https://archive.fo/WY5IJ

What are the changes made to the December 2021 restrictions?    Starting from 15 December, the following restrictions shall apply:    Max. 75% passenger capacity in public transport  Max. 30% seating capacity in restaurants, bars, hotels, cinemas, theaters, sports and religious facilities. An increase in the limit is possible only for vaccinated persons, after verification by the entrepreneur on the basis of a COVID-19 certificate.  From 15 December, clubs, discos and other places for dancing will be closed. They will be allowed to operate exclusively on New Year's Eve (31/12-1/01) under sanitary regime (max. 100 people, COVID-19 certificate holders not included).      10/12/21  CULTURAL EVENTS - RESTRICTIONS    Museums and art galleries    Museums and art galleries are open and can operate under a strict sanitary regime. A limit of 1 person per 10 m2 is in effect.    Cinemas    Cinemas have resumed both outdoor and indoor activities. They operate under a strict sanitary regime at no more than 50% occupancy. Wearing masks covering both mouth and nose is mandatory.    Theatres, operas, and philharmonics    Outdoors:    Theaters, operas and philharmonic halls have resumed their activities in the open air. They operate under a strict sanitary regime at no more than 50% occupancy. No more than 250 attendees are allowed.    This number does not include persons vaccinated against COVID-19.    Indoors:    Theaters, operas and philharmonic halls have resumed their indoor activity. They operate under a strict sanitary regime at no more than 50% occupancy. Event organisers must ensure that the limit of 1 person per 10 m2 is observed. Wearing masks covering both mouth and nose is mandatory.    Cultural and community centres    Cultural and community centres may conduct activities both outdoors and indoors, provided that the number of attendees does not exceed 15 people and a distance of 1.5 m between them is maintained, and that participants comply with the requirement to cover mouth and nose.    Concerts and circus shows    Indoor concert activities have been resumed under the following conditions:    no more than 50% of seats may be made available to viewers or listeners,  a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners must be maintained, and if no designated seats are available, a limit of 1 person per 10 metres squared must be observed,  ensuring that viewers or listeners comply with the requirement to cover mouth and nose.  Concerts and circus performances can be organised outdoors under the following conditions:    no more than 50% of seats may be made available to viewers or listeners,  a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners must be maintained, and if no designated seats are available, a limit of 1 person per 15 metres squared must be observed; additionally, no more than 250 attendees are allowed. Persons vaccinated against Covid-19 shall not count towards the limit.  ensuring that viewers or listeners comply with the requirement to cover mouth and nose.  Entertainment â Outdoor amusement parks    Outdoor amusement parks can resume operations at up to 50% occupancy.    Libraries    Libraries may make their collections available to readers provided that the limit of 1 person per 10 m2 of space is observed; librarians shall not count towards this limit. Information on the limit of persons allowed into the library shall be posted at the libraryâs entrance.    Public and research libraries may organise indoor meetings and events provided that the following criteria are met:    no more than 15 attendees are allowed, with each of them maintaining a distance of 1.5 m from other persons;  ensuring that attendees comply with the requirement to cover mouth and nose.  PUBLIC TRANSPORT  Public transport vehicles may be boarded by a limited number of persons.    All means of public transport across Poland may only make up to 100% of seats available to passengers (75% from 15 December)         RELIGIOUS CEREMONIES    We also recommend that all ceremonies be held outdoors.Tthere is a limit in places of religious worship - a max. 50% of full capacity.    Important! In churches and places of worship it is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose.    The limit shall not apply to persons fully vaccinated against COVID-19.         GATHERINGS AND MEETINGS  GATHERINGS    Up to 100 people may participate in a public gathering at the same time. Participants are required to maintain a distance of 1.5 m from others. Additionally, the distance between individual gatherings must be at least 100 m.    MEETINGS    Up to 100 people may participate in events and meetings, either outdoors, indoors or in designated gastronomic areas. A distance between individual tables must be maintained (only every other table may be occupied, with a 1.5 m distance between tables â unless there is a screen between them with a height of at least 1 m, counting from the tableâs surface).    This number does not include persons vaccinated against COVID-19.         WEDDINGS, COMMUNIONS, FUNERAL RECEPTIONS AND OTHER CELEBRATIONS  Special events may be organised outdoors and indoors alike (e.g. inside restaurants). A limit of 150 attendees is in effect. Such events may only take place under a strict sanitary regime. A distance between individual tables must be maintained (only every other table may be occupied, with a 1.5 m distance between tables â unless there is a screen between them with a height of at least 1 m, counting from the tableâs surface).    This number does not include persons vaccinated against COVID-19.         NIGHT CLUBS, DISCOS AND OTHER PLACES FOR DANCING  Night clubs, discos and other dancing venues resumed their activities. The limit of max. 100 people will apply.    This number does not include persons vaccinated against COVID-19.         FAIRS, EXHIBITIONS, CONGRESSES AND CONFERENCES  Trade fairs, congresses and conferences can be organised provided that the limit of 1 person per 10 m2 is complied with.    https://archive.fo/wS5eU

Public transport  Throughout the country, public transport can transport no more than 100% of passengers at the same time. occupancy. Remember to cover your face with a mask.    https://archive.fo/bSHzo

Public transport  Throughout the country, public transport can transport no more than 100% of passengers at the same time. occupancy. Remember to cover your face with a mask.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  From 1.11, the obligation to cover the mouth and nose will be introduced in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     https://archive.fo/WY5IJ

RESTRICTIONS CONCERNING MOVEMENT    1.5 METER â MINIMUM DISTANCE BETWEEN PEDESTRIANS  It is mandatory that a distance of least 1.5 meters be maintained between pedestrians.    The following persons are exempt from the restriction:    parents with children who require care (younger than 13),  persons who live in one household or run a household together,  disabled persons, persons incapable of moving on their own, persons with a special educational needs statement and their carers.  COVERING YOUR MOUTH AND NOSE ONLY WITH A MASK IN PUBLIC SPACES    It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose in such places as:    in buses, trams and trains,  in shops, malls, banks, markets and post offices  in cinemas and theatres,  at physicianâs offices, in outpatient clinics and hospitals, in massage and tattoo parlours  in churches, at schools and universities,  In government offices (when going there to take care of certain matters) and other civic centres.  Where is it not mandatory to cover your mouth and nose? In forests, parks, green squares, botanical gardens, historic gardens, family community gardens and on beaches as well as while travelling by private car.    Important!  Exemption from the obligation to cover the mouth and nose is limited only to persons who have a medical certificate or a document confirming:    a pervasive developmental disorder,  a mental disorder,  moderate, severe or profound intellectual disability,  difficulties in uncovering the mouth or nose on their own.  Covering the mouth and nose in public spaces is obligatory throughout the entire country.    Important! You may only use a mask to cover your mouth and nose. Scarves or face shields are not allowed because they do not fulfil their main function, which is to provide protection against the virus!      https://archive.fo/wS5eU

Important! From November 30 to December 27, flights are banned from Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.    People returning from these countries cannot be released from quarantine for 14 days.    The provisions on quarantine do not apply to people who have:    EU digital COVID certification for COVID-19 vaccination, COVID-19 infection or negative COVID-19 test;  certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery due to COVID-19 recognized as equivalent to the EU COVID Certificate.    https://archive.fo/wrcIU

International borders and movement  Check the website of the Border Guard  for the rules of entry and stay in the territory of the Republic of Poland.    Important! From November 30 to January 10, flights are banned from Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa and Zimbabwe.    People returning from these countries cannot be released from quarantine for 14 days.    The provisions on quarantine do not apply to people who have:    EU digital COVID certification for COVID-19 vaccination, COVID-19 infection or negative COVID-19 test;  certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery due to COVID-19 recognized as equivalent to the EU COVID Certificate.  Attention! From December 15, people arriving from outside the Schengen area must have a COVID 19 test performed within 24 hours prior to crossing the border, starting from the test result.    Vaccination does not release you from the obligation to perform the test. From December 18, the test does not need to be carried out by children under the age of 5.    It is also possible to perform a test at some airports in Poland, before the border check. We encourage you to verify the information on the websites of individual airports. From 18 December, the test can be performed at the airport within 3 hours of crossing the border.    Remember! People traveling from outside the European Union, from outside the Schengen area and from outside Turkey cannot be released from quarantine on the basis of a test performed within 48 hours after returning to Poland. This possibility is allowed only after 8 days. The obligation to undergo quarantine is deemed to be fulfilled when the negative test result is entered by the medical diagnostic laboratory into the ICT system.    Important!  Persons who, after arrival, stay in the territory of the Republic of Poland for no longer than 24 hours and have a flight ticket confirming departure from the territory of the Republic of Poland within 24 hours, are exempt from the obligation to undergo quarantine.    From July 17, a person crossing the state border of the Republic of Poland by plane - before checking in - must fill in the traveler location card.    More details in the For travelers tab  !    International rail traffic  The movement of passengers in rail transport, with the crossing of the Polish border with the Republic of Belarus, is suspended.    Valid until December 31st    https://archive.fo/gBEb5

I have symptoms characteristic of COVID-19. What should I do first?  If your symptoms are typical of the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection, contact your primary care physician via a teleconsultation. Your doctor may have you tested for the coronavirus.    If the doctor you have chosen as your GP is not on duty, your GPâs outpatient clinic will refer you to the doctor on duty who will replace him/her at that time and who has the right to issue a referral for a test.    Use the primary care clinic search engine at: https://zip.nfz.gov.pl/GSL/GSL/POZ    You cannot get a referral for a coronavirus test from a doctor on duty as part of a night or holiday medical telecare services. You must wait until your clinic opens. If you are feeling very bad, call 112. Make sure to say that you probably have COVID-19.    https://archive.fo/4vrJg

Can a test referral only be issued by a GP? Can a doctor from night and holiday telephoto issue such a referral?  An order for a coronavirus test can be issued by a doctor on duty as part of night or holiday health care.    You can also sign up for an online test. All you have to do is fill in the form available at gov.pl/dom . You will be asked to answer a few questions. Based on the data you provide, the system will determine if you qualify for the test.    How it's working?    Go to gov.pl/dom and click the "Form" button.  Answer the survey questions.  If the system qualifies you for the test, a consultant from the Home Medical Care Monitoring Center will contact you.  You will receive an order for the test from the eKolejka system.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

If the system qualifies you for the test, a consultant from the Home Medical Care Monitoring Center will contact you.  You will receive an order for the test from the eKolejka system.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

The Polish Government has launched two apps (âKwarantanna domowaâ app and âSTOP COVID - ProteGO Safeâ app).    The âKwarantanna domowaâ application is intended for people who are subject to 10-day mandatory house quarantine due to suspected COVID-19 exposure. The application uses geolocation and face recognition technology to ensure that relevant people are quarantined.    The âSTOP COVID - ProteGO Safeâ application is designed to allow users to monitor their level of risk of getting infected. The app facilitates self-assessment of the risk of COVID-19 infection and, if the user decides to do so, it allows the user to scan the environment for other smartphones on which the application is installed and saves the history of anonymous identifiers encountered    https://web.archive.org/web/20211001112735/https://www.nortonrosefulbright.com/en-pl/knowledge/publications/d7a9a296/contact-tracing-apps-a-new-world-for-data-privacy#poland

I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

COVERING YOUR MOUTH AND NOSE ONLY WITH A MASK IN PUBLIC SPACES  It is mandatory to cover your mouth and nose in such places as:  in buses, trams and trains,  in shops, malls, banks, markets and post offices  in cinemas and theatres,  at physicianâs offices, in outpatient clinics and hospitals, in massage and tattoo parlours  in churches, at schools and universities,  In government offices (when going there to take care of certain matters) and other civic centres.  Where is it not mandatory to cover your mouth and nose? In forests, parks, green squares, botanical gardens, historic gardens, family community gardens and on beaches as well as while travelling by private car.  Important!  Exemption from the obligation to cover the mouth and nose is limited only to persons who have a medical certificate or a document confirming:  a pervasive developmental disorder,  a mental disorder,  moderate, severe or profound intellectual disability,  difficulties in uncovering the mouth or nose on their own.  Covering the mouth and nose in public spaces is obligatory throughout the entire country.  Important! You may only use a mask to cover your mouth and nose. Scarves or face shields are not allowed because they do not fulfil their main function, which is to provide protection against the virus!    https://archive.fo/wS5eU#selection-687.0-789.202

Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  From 1.11, the obligation to cover the mouth and nose will be introduced in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20211216160956/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

RESTRICTIONS CONCERNING MOVEMENT    1.5 METER â MINIMUM DISTANCE BETWEEN PEDESTRIANS  It is mandatory that a distance of least 1.5 meters be maintained between pedestrians.    The following persons are exempt from the restriction:    parents with children who require care (younger than 13),  persons who live in one household or run a household together,  disabled persons, persons incapable of moving on their own, persons with a special educational needs statement and their carers. International Entry RestrictionsRomania designates countries as Green, Yellow, or Red depending on local infection rates and the presence of virus variants. Travelers from Green countries may enter Romania without restriction. Travelers from Yellow and Red countries must self-isolate for 14 days on arrival; however, travelers from Yellow countries are exempt from isolation if they can present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival, or can end isolation early at any point following a negative PCR test. Travelers from Red countries can end self-isolation after 10 days following a negative PCR test taken on day eight of isolation. Additionally, travelers who have completed a full course of vaccination against COVID-19 at least 10 days before arrival in Romania, or who have recovered from COVID-19 between 14-180 days before arriving in the country are exempt from the quarantine requirement. Arrivals from the U.K. must possess a negative PCR test taken within 72 hours prior to arrival and self-isolate for 14 days. Additional quarantine exemptions are in place for cross-border workers, transport workers, individuals in transit, and certain categories of essential work.    Entering Romania is forbidden to travellers arriving from Angola, Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    https://archive.vn/fcQ6f  https://archive.vn/Iq8SL

It appears that vaccination was universal very early in 2021 (18th of January). Some regions have made vaccinations compulsory for some workers (such as service sector) but president Putin is opposing mandatoring vaccination. The campaign is going on at a very slow rate. Russia is offering incentives to get vaccinated.     They have approved a new jab (Sputnik M) as well as a nasal vaccine that could be distributed soon.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206142656/https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-covid-anti-vax-celebrities/31576990.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206102434/https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/russias-putin-gets-covid-19-booster-jab  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206135140/https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-coronavirus-surge-covid/31514957.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206135223/https://www.rferl.org/a/russia-covid-deaths/31558145.html

Travellers from "at-risk" countries, including South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Mozambique and Malawi, are PCR-tested at the airport. If test positive, they would be sent to a hospital, while those tested negatively would have to go into quarantine.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211201182936/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/coronavirus-omicron-starin-straightens-measures-at-serbias-bordrer-crossings/

For most arrivals, it is enough to have negative test results (48 hours), recovery or vaccination certificate. Further introduced is mandatory quarantine to those that visited South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Mozambique and Malawi.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213105951/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/serbia/entry-requirements

Foreigners coming to the Republic of Serbia is allowed to enter the Republic of Serbia only if you have a negative RT-PCR test for the presence of SARS-CoV-2, no more than 48 hours, issued by foreign reference laboratories of the country from which they come, i.e. from which they enter the Republic of Serbia.  If the person has a vaccine or recovery certificiate showing that the vaccine or recovery happened less than 6 months ago but more than 14 days ago, are not required to provide a test if it is a country with which Serbia has concluded an agreement on reciprocal acceptance of vaccine and recovery certificates.    https://archive.fo/ej5ea

Only workers who are unable to complete their work at home are permitted to enter workplace, and to do so must be either fully vaccinated, have a negative test within the last 7 days, or have proof of full recovery from COVID-19 (known as the OP regime). The Slovak government is still in a state of emergency. Only gatherings with up to 6 people are allowed if all participants are either vaccinated or recovered. There are few exceptions and some public events can take place with limited capacity (official assemblies, funerals, professional sport). But generally public events are greatly restricted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213104738/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

All participants will be in OP mode at the time of the start of the mass event ; the maximum capacity of such a mass event is 10 people   https://web.archive.org/web/20211219220248/https://automat.gov.sk/bratislava

Mass events are prohibited. Their are limited expectations including meeting for work purposes (with a limit of 10 people, all of whom must be vaccinated or fully recovered), weddings and baptisms (limit of 6 people), and funerals (no capacity limits). There are set measures for events going ahead have including face coverings, proof of the number of people who are attending, and reservation of a venue.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229123427/https://automat.gov.sk/bratislava?detail

With effect from 10 December 2021, the gathering of a state of emergency shall prohibit the gathering of more than 6 persons, except for persons living in the same household.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213104738/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/
The restriction is on 6 people, except people living in one household.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213104738/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

Gatherings of more than 6 people, unless living in the same household, are prohibited.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229123630/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

Public transport is still open, though subject to curfew rules and social distancing measures.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229120254/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Curfew was introduced on 11/25/2021 and remains in place. All residents are required to stay at home from 5 am until 1 am the next day. Exemptions from curfew are visiting a doctor; travelling to get vaccinated or a Covid-19 test (between 5:00 and 20:00); the essential shopping and services - opening hours limited between 5:00 and 20:00; commuting to and from work (with home office recommended), employees will need confirmation from their employer; travel to and from school and kindergarten (between 5:00 and 20:00); care for family members or other relatives; walking pets within 500m from your home, caring for farm animals; being in nature within the district you live; attending funerals, wedding ceremonies and christenings (between 5:00 and 20:00); travel abroad and to mass events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213104738/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

Curfew was introduced on 11/25/2021, all residents are required to stay at home from 5 am until 1 am the next day. Exemptions from curfew are visiting a doctor; travelling to get vaccinated or a Covid-19 test (between 5:00 and 20:00); the essential shopping and services - opening hours limited between 5:00 and 20:00; commuting to and from work (with home office recommended), employees will need confirmation from their employer; travel to and from school and kindergarten (between 5:00 and 20:00); care for family members or other relatives; walking pets within 500m from your home, caring for farm animals; being in nature within the district you live; attending funerals, wedding ceremonies and christenings (between 5:00 and 20:00);  travel abroad and to mass events.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206182423/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22790201/slovakia-enters-all-out-lockdown.html?ref=njctse  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206180117/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

A national curfew from 20.00 to 05.00 the next day is in place, with people required to stay at home during this time expect for a restricted list of essential purposes.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229123630/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

Stay at home requirement imposed, but no explicit restrictions on internal movement.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206180117/https://korona.gov.sk/nudzovy-stav-a-zakaz-vychadzania-od-25-novembra-2021/

Whilst curfew rules are in place, interval movement outside of these times is not recommended to stop or is prohibited. From 10 December, travelling on some long-distance buses and trains has required proof of vaccination, recovery or testing to use.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229120510/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/coronavirus  Source

Additionally to the 14-day quarantine requirement for all unvaccinated arrivals, from 12/01/2021 all persons who during the previous 14 days visited the Republic of South Africa, Botswana, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Israel, Hong Kong or Seychelles will have to quarantine regardless their vaccination status. This has been the response to spreading the omicron variant.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206191753/https://www.mzv.sk/documents/10182/4369283/vyhlaska_hranice_EN.pdf/1eea00e2-5239-4af9-8f72-7b41aa988580

Persons who have visited the Republic of South Africa, Botswana, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Israel, Hong Kong or the Seychelles in the last 14 days and who enter the territory of the Slovak Republic from 1 December 2021 must enter quarantine, which will end in asymptomatic completion of its isolation on day 14 or by receiving two negative results from RT-PCR tests for COVID-19, whereby laboratory diagnosis of COVID-19 can be made first on the first day of isolation and then on the eighth day of isolation. In children under the age of twelve and two months of age, with an asymptomatic course of isolation, this ends with the termination of the obligation of home isolation for persons living in the same household.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213105530/https://korona.gov.sk/cestovanie-do-sr/

In children under the age of twelve and two months of age, with an asymptomatic course of isolation, this ends with the termination of the obligation of home isolation for persons living in the same household.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211213105530/https://korona.gov.sk/cestovanie-do-sr/

Contact tracing services are limited. People who test positive are asked to tell their doctor and anyone they have been in close contact with in the 2 days before symptom onset.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229121805/https://korona.gov.sk/en/

All persons are ordered to properly cover the upper respiratory tract (nose and mouth) using a respirator in public in all areas of building interiors, public transport, taxi services or other transport with persons who are not members of the common household. All persons at outdoor and mass events are ordered to properly cover the upper respiratory tract (nose and mouth) using a respirator or other preventive protective equipment, such as a scarf.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211206195134/https://korona.gov.sk/povinnost-nosit-ruska-a-respiratory/

Masks are required everywhere outside the home if another person is closer than 2 meters and few other exceptions (ex. children, weddings).  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206195134/https://korona.gov.sk/povinnost-nosit-ruska-a-respiratory/

A standard face mask is required in all outdoor events, and when less than 2 metres away from people outside of your household outdoors. FFP2-standard face masks are required at all indoor venues and areas.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211229120510/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovakia/coronavirus

28th Dec 2021,  Advice and recommendations  - Keep your distance from other people in public settings, especially indoors.  - If possible, adults should avoid crowded public transport by choosing to travel at times other than during rush hour or using other means of transport, such as walking, cycling or travelling by car.  - Adults should use face masks on public transport if crowding cannot be avoided.  - Anyone with symptoms of Covid-19 should stay at home.   - Anyone with symptoms over the age of six who has not had covid-19 in the past six months should get tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220104084446/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/current-rules-and-recommendations

Dec 16 (Reuters) - Sweden will require visitors from other Nordic nations to have a vaccine pass to cross the border as it tightens restrictions in the face of rising number of COVID-19 infections and worries about the Omicron variant.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211228120622/https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/sweden-extend-vaccine-pass-rules-nordic-travellers-2021-12-16/

22 December 2021,  Negative COVID-19 test required for entry into Sweden.    Due to the high occurrence of COVID-19 around the world and the increasing spread of the Omicron variant, the Public Health Agency of Sweden has requested that the Government present stricter entry restrictions. The Government has therefore decided to introduce a requirement that a negative test result for ongoing COVID-19 infection must be presented when entering Sweden.    The test for ongoing COVID-19 infection must have been conducted within 48 hours prior to arrival to Sweden.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220104085946/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2021/12/negative-covid-19-test-required-for-entry-into-sweden/

22 December 2021, Negative COVID-19 test required for entry into Sweden.    Due to the high occurrence of COVID-19 around the world and the increasing spread of the Omicron variant, the Public Health Agency of Sweden has requested that the Government present stricter entry restrictions. The Government has therefore decided to introduce a requirement that a negative test result for ongoing COVID-19 infection must be presented when entering Sweden.    The test for ongoing COVID-19 infection must have been conducted within 48 hours prior to arrival to Sweden.    The test requirement applies:  - To foreign nationals travelling from EU/EEA countries, including the Nordic countries, or from other countries, with certain exemptions  regardless of whether they have been vaccinated or have recovered  - To adults and children over the age of 12.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220104085946/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2021/12/negative-covid-19-test-required-for-entry-into-sweden/

31st Dec 2021, Ban on entry to Sweden from countries outside the EU/EEA and Switzerland    There is a ban on non-essential travel to Sweden from countries outside the EU/EEA. This ban applies to foreign nationals and remains in effect until 31 January 2022. There are a number of exemptions to the ban based on work or studies, family connections or urgent family reasons, as well as a number of countries whose residents are exempted.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220104083757/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/travel-restrictions

No policy change. Schools in red areas of Ukraine must close, with schools in other areas permitted to re-open only if at least 80% of the staff are vaccinated; if this isn't the case, students must continue their studies via online learning.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211215153430/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse & http://web.archive.org/web/20211215153631/https://covid19.gov.ua/osvita-ta-batkivstvo

Most schools are only remotely. The whole country is at least in the yellow phase, so only institutions with over 80% vaccinated staff can continue teaching in person. Most country is in the red phase, where a 100% vaccination rate is required among teachers.   https://archive.ph/lD8eg  https://archive.ph/PTjyn  https://archive.ph/WN3J0

No policy change. Businesses told to organise conditions for employees to be able to work remotely to prevent spread of the virus  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211215153745/https://covid19.gov.ua/en & http://web.archive.org/web/20211215155200/https://covid19.gov.ua/yak-zakhystyty-sebe-ta-ridnykh
Just general guidelines regarding safety measures. No change.  https://archive.ph/Z9GoA  https://archive.ph/WN3J0

In âyellowâ and âorangeâ and "red" zones, mass events are prohibited unless all staff and participants have one of the following: a certificate of full vaccination (within the last 365 days), a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 (within the last 105 days) or a certificate of a negative PCR or rapid-antigen test (within the last 72 hours).  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211215154717/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ukraine/coronavirus

Events can go forward, but with some restrictions. Generally 1 person per 4 sq meters or up to a certain level of capacity (yellow 2/3, red 1/2). Additionally, participants should present either test results, vaccination card or recovery confirmation.   https://archive.ph/Z9GoA  https://archive.ph/WN3J0

The government allows gatherings of up to 50 people, as well as indoor religious events, provided there is 1 person per 5 sq m and a 1.5 metre distance is maintained between individuals   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211215153745/https://covid19.gov.ua/en
No change, limit to 50 people.  https://archive.ph/Z9GoA

Public transport is open with social distancing measures in place. All passengers are to wear masks and the number of passengers in the transport vehicle is to be equal to the number of sitting places.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20211215153745/https://covid19.gov.ua/en
Capacity is limited to seats and mask-wearing is required.  https://archive.ph/vBLZ7
No policy found.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211215153745/https://covid19.gov.ua/en
No policy.  https://archive.ph/Z9GoA  https://archive.ph/WN3J0

Domestic flights are operating, although at a reduced schedule. A vaccine certificate or negative PCR or express-test taken within 72 hours of travel is required if travelling inter-city (by train, bus or plane) to or from a âyellowâ, âorangeâ or âredâ zone.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211215154717/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ukraine/coronavirus

For inter-state travel between regions in the yellow and red phase, passengers in buses, trains and planes need to show a vaccination card, test result or recovery confirmation. This rule does not apply to passenger cars.  https://archive.ph/WN3J0  https://archive.ph/t0Qe3  https://archive.ph/3L3GZ

Foreign nationals without a residence permit who have spent more than 7 of the past 14 days in the nations of South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, Lesotho, Eswatini, Mozambique or Malawi, are not permitted to enter Ukraine. Those with a residence permit or exemption may enter, but must self-isolate for 14 days (a negative test will not shorten the period of isolation required).  For travellers from all other nations, foreign nationals are required to provide proof of health insurance that covers COVID-19 observation and treatment for the duration of their stay. Additionally, must show proof that they have received at least one dose of the approved vaccines (AstraZeneca (Vaxzevria, Covishield and SKBio), Janssen, Moderna, Sinopharm and CoronaVac) or a negative PCR / rapid antigen test taken in the last 72 hours. Those who fail to present this information will have to self-isolate until they receive a negative PCR result.   Travellers from Russia are exempt from these rules.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211215154717/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/ukraine/coronavirus

For all travellers, there is a requirement to show test result, vaccination card or recovery confirmation upon arrival. People that spent time in specific countries are required to quarantine, regardless of their documents (the list includes: the Republic of South Africa, the Republic of Botswana, Zimbabwe, Namibia, the Kingdom of Lesotho, the Kingdom of Eswatini, the Republic of Mozambique and the Republic of Malawi).  https://archive.ph/t0Qe3  https://archive.ph/3L3GZ

Covid-19 tests are widely available at the expense of the individual. Average cost of a PCR Covid-19 test is 40 USD.?  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20211216160930/https://ua.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Thanks to WHO-EU cooperation Ukraine was able to build up its testing capacity. Generally available, but needs to be purchased.  https://archive.ph/vBLZ7  https://archive.ph/YjcXv  https://archive.ph/MxcLw

Quote: "Uzbekistan will tighten international entry restrictions in order to limit the spread of the COVID-19 Omicron variant, Dec. 3-Jan. 10, 2022. All incoming, outgoing, and transit flights with South Africa, Botswana, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Madagascar, Lesotho, Tanzania, eSwatini, and Hong Kong will be suspended. Additionally, nonresident foreign nationals who have been in one of these countries within the previous 14 days will not be permitted to enter Uzbekistan.    International Travel RestrictionsAuthorities currently maintain a number of other international entry restrictions. All travelers entering Uzbekistan via rail or air must present proof of a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival in a testing laboratory approved by authorities.    Persons entering Uzbekistan at vehicle border checkpoints must take a rapid antigen test at specialized facilities operating at the border at their own expense. Uzbek nationals who test positive will be quarantined in a government facility, while foreign nationals that test positive will be barred from entry. Travelers from certain countries may be required to self-isolate for 14 days on arrival."  Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20211207064049/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551591/uzbekistan-authorities-to-suspend-flights-with-multiple-southern-african-nations-and-hong-kong-from-dec-3-due-to-covid-19-omicron-variant-update-35
